query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Studies have identified several methods for controlling disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms. For sea lice control, two studies in Ireland found mixed effects of using cleaner wrasse - corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks. Altering lighting intensity was found to reduce lice numbers, with lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulting in fewer lice. Fallowing systems showed mixed results, with one study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers but another in Australia finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease. For disease prevention and control, vaccinations were found to increase survival rates against various pathogens including Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia in studies from Iceland, Norway, Australia and Canada. Using probiotics and immunostimulants showed benefits including increased survival when salmon were exposed to disease-causing bacteria, with one study finding a 28% reduction in lice infection when fish were fed a diet with 28% plant-based protein, and a further 28% reduction when beta-glucans were added. Freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease showed mixed results, with one study finding reduced amoebae on gills for up to 10 days, while another found no difference between treated and untreated salmon.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "Atlantic salmon disease sea lice control methods", "k": 10}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

{
  "action_id": "733",
  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}

{
  "action_id": "2587",
  "action_title": "Use drugs to treat parasites",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seven studies evaluated the effects on mammals of using drugs to treat parasites. Three studies were in the USA, two were in Spain, one was in Germany and one was in Croatia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Survival (1 study): A randomized, replicated, controlled study the USA found that medical treatment of Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep against lungworm did not increase lamb survival.
Condition (6 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (one controlled), in Germany, the USA and Croatia, found that after administering drugs to mammals, parasite burdens were reduced in roe deer and in wild boar piglets and numbers of white-tailed deer infected were reduced. A third study found that levels of lungworm larvae in bighorn sheep faeces were reduced one month after drug treatment but not after three to seven months. One of these studies also found that the drug treatment resulted in increased body weight in roe deer fawns. A replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that higher doses of ivermectin treated sarcoptic mange in Spanish ibex faster than lower doses, and treatment was more effective in animals with less severe infections. A replicated, before-and-after study in Spain found that after injecting Spanish ibex with ivermectin to treat sarcoptic mange a mange-free herd was established.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary:
Based on multiple studies from Norway, plant-based protein alternatives to fish meal generally result in decreased growth rates in Atlantic salmon. Six studies found reduced growth rates with plant-based diets, while three studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal controls. Plant-based diets also showed reduced final body weights in four studies, with mixed effects on feeding efficiency - some studies showed lowered efficiency while others showed increased efficiency. Fish meal reduction studies found no significant differences in final weights.

Bacterial protein alternatives showed more favorable results. Two replicated controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates when bacterial protein replaced up to 25% of fish meal, though 50% replacement resulted in lower growth rates. Another study actually reported higher growth rates with diets containing 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to fish meal controls, suggesting bacterial protein may be superior to plant-based alternatives in maintaining salmon growth performance.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "plant-based protein fish meal Atlantic salmon growth rates Norway", "k": 10}
{"k": 10, "query_string": "bacterial protein Atlantic salmon growth performance fish meal replacement"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from controlled studies, several interventions show effectiveness for increasing survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease. Vaccinations demonstrated higher survival rates across multiple studies, including protection against Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia. Breeding for resistance traits showed increased survival in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis. Use of probiotics and immunostimulants increased survival against disease-causing bacteria and reduced lice infection by 28% while also improving gut function. Aerobic training resulted in higher survival rates for salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training being more effective than continuous training. Establishing fallowing systems showed mixed results, with reduced lice numbers in one study but no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in another.

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated, controlled studies found that digestibility of feed components by salmon was lower when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal, while two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway found similar levels of digestibility across both diet types. Two studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However, morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies.

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary:
Based on the research evidence, several non-chemical alternatives exist for controlling sea lice on salmon farms. The use of cleaner wrasse as natural control agents shows mixed results - corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were found to be as effective as chemical treatments in one controlled study in Ireland, while rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks in another study. Altering lighting conditions is another non-chemical approach, with a replicated, controlled study in Norway showing that lower numbers of lice were found on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting, where higher intensity artificial light led to higher lice numbers.

Fallowing systems represent another alternative, with a study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using this approach, though another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease where fallowing had been used. Probiotics and immunostimulants show promise - a replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before bacterial exposure, while a Norwegian study found that feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced lice infection by 28%, and adding beta-glucans decreased infection levels by a further 28% compared to controls.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "sea lice salmon farms non-chemical control alternatives", "k": 5}

A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

query: How does the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control vary between studies in Scotland and Australia?
relevant_summary: Studies comparing the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control show contrasting results between Scotland and Australia. In Scotland, a study found that fallowing systems successfully reduced sea lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages (action 1026). However, in Australia, research found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing systems had been used (action 1026). The evidence suggests that fallowing may be effective for controlling parasites like sea lice in Scottish waters, but shows no beneficial effect against Amoebic Gill Disease in Australian salmon farming operations.

{
  "action_id": "2191",
  "action_title": "Leave a fallow period during fish/shellfish farming",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies examined the effects of leaving a fallow period during fish farming on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations. Two studies were in the Tasman Sea (Australia), and one in the North Pacific Ocean (USA).

 
COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Overall community composition (2 study): Two replicated, before-and-after, site comparison study in the Tasman Sea found that after a fallow period invertebrate community composition became similar to that occurring before the fish were added but remained different to communities at sites without fish farms.
Worm community composition (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after, site comparison study in the North Pacific Ocean found that after a fallow period polychaete worm community composition changed but remained different to communities at sites without fish farms.
Worm richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after, site comparison study in the North Pacific Ocean found that after a fallow period polychaete worm diversity did not change and remained lower compared to sites without fish farms.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Worm abundance (2 studies): Two replicated, before-and-after, site comparison studies in the Tasman Sea and the North Pacific Ocean found that following a fallow period, abundances of pollution-indicator polychaete worms decreased, but remained higher compared to sites without fish farms."
}

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: Studies show that krill meal and yeast meal produce similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal, while animal protein alternatives result in lower weight. Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed diets containing fish meal only or krill meal substitutes, with feed conversion ratios being similar between fish meal and krill meal diets. One study found that when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fish meal compared to leaving the krill whole. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal. However, one controlled, randomized, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with animal proteins.

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary:
Norwegian studies on alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets have shown mixed results:

Genetically Modified Alternatives: Three controlled, replicated studies (two randomized) found no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed GM versus non-GM soybeans. One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in fish histology between GM and non-GM soy diets.

Yeast Protein: One replicated, controlled experiment found no differences in weight between salmon fed diets containing Yarrowia lipolytica yeast compared to fishmeal control diets.

Plant-Based Protein: Multiple studies found that plant-based proteins decreased growth rates and final body weights in some cases, while other studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal diets. Some studies showed reduced feeding efficiency and digestibility with plant proteins, altered intestinal morphology, but no effects on survival rates or appetite.

Bacterial Protein: Two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% fish meal was replaced with bacterial protein, but lower growth rates at 50% replacement. Another study reported higher growth rates with 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion.

Vegetable Oil: Three replicated studies (two controlled) found similar growth rates between fish oil and vegetable oil diets, with some studies finding higher growth rates with vegetable oil. Studies showed that fatty acid profiles reflected the oil source, with no effects on broodstock fecundity, egg weights, or fertility rates. Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyl concentrations in salmon flesh.

Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Norway found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets.
Three studies (two replicated, one controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected oil source within diets.
A study in Norway found that oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity levels, egg weights, fertility rates, as well as the weights and development of resultant fry.
One replicated Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to the fish oil diet. One replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland found salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh, compared with diets containing fish oil.
A replicated study in Norway found that fresh, frozen and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture and liquid holding capacity. Pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets."
}

{"query": "What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?", "summary": "Norwegian studies on alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets have shown mixed results:

Genetically Modified Alternatives: Three controlled, replicated studies (two randomized) found no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed GM versus non-GM soybeans. One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in fish histology between GM and non-GM soy diets.

Yeast Protein: One replicated, controlled experiment found no differences in weight between salmon fed diets containing Yarrowia lipolytica yeast compared to fishmeal control diets.

Plant-Based Protein: Multiple studies found that plant-based proteins decreased growth rates and final body weights in some cases, while other studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal diets. Some studies showed reduced feeding efficiency and digestibility with plant proteins, altered intestinal morphology, but no effects on survival rates or appetite.

Bacterial Protein: Two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% fish meal was replaced with bacterial protein, but lower growth rates at 50% replacement. Another study reported higher growth rates with 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion.

Vegetable Oil: Three replicated studies (two controlled) found similar growth rates between fish oil and vegetable oil diets, with some studies finding higher growth rates with vegetable oil. Studies showed that fatty acid profiles reflected the oil source, with no effects on broodstock fecundity, egg weights, or fertility rates. Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyl concentrations in salmon flesh.", "action_ids": ["928", "920", "924", "918", "926"]}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2695",
  "action_title": "Use artificial light on fishing gear",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies examined the effects of using artificial light on fishing gear on marine fish populations. One study was in the Pacific Ocean (USA) and one in the Barents Sea (Norway). 

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Reduction of unwanted catch (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in the Pacific Ocean found that shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights caught fewer unwanted fish when they were fitted to the fishing line, but not to a size-sorting grid, compared to a conventional trawl.
Improved size-selectivity of fishing gear (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the Barents Sea found that size-selectivity of long rough dab, Atlantic cod, haddock and redfish was not improved by the presence of LED lights on a size-sorting grid."
}

query: How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?
relevant_summary: Freshwater bathing for amoebic gill disease shows mixed effectiveness in studies. Two studies in Australia found that while one study showed a reduction in numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing, one replicated controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon. For fallowing systems, the effectiveness varies by disease type. A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system. However, an Australian study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used. An additional benefit was noted where a trial in Tasmania found sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence, several dietary alternatives and supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight. Taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain compared to diets without taurine (Action ID: 930). Similarly, phytase and phosphate supplementation showed no difference in weight gain in one Australian study, while another Australian study actually found greater final weights in salmon fed diets supplemented with phytase (Action ID: 930). Genetically modified soybeans used as an alternative to fish meal resulted in no difference in growth rate compared to non-GM soybeans (Action ID: 928). Krill meal as a substitute for fish meal resulted in similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios compared to fish meal diets (Action ID: 916). Yeast protein from Yarrowia lipolytica showed no differences in weight compared to control fishmeal diets (Action ID: 920). Additionally, diets with low, medium, or high levels of fish meal resulted in similar final weights (Action ID: 915). Plant-based oil sources as alternatives to fish oil showed similar or even higher growth rates in salmon (Action ID: 926).

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "Atlantic salmon fish meal dietary alternatives supplements growth weight", "k": 10}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

{
  "action_id": "926",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative oil source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway found growth rates were similar in salmon that were fed diets containing fish oil and vegetable oil. One replicated study in Norway found growth rates were higher in fish fed diets containing vegetable oil.  One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, dependant on family genetics.
Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Norway found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets.
Three studies (two replicated, one controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected oil source within diets.
A study in Norway found that oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity levels, egg weights, fertility rates, as well as the weights and development of resultant fry.
One replicated Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to the fish oil diet. One replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil.
A replicated, controlled study in Scotland found salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh, compared with diets containing fish oil.
A replicated study in Norway found that fresh, frozen and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture and liquid holding capacity. Pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets."
}

{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}
